Situation1: Both have several free evenings this week and can choose any for a date.
Situation2: They manage high-value transactions at the end of a shift, where mistakes could cause significant financial discrepancies.
Story: I glanced at my phone during a lull at the register, my boyfriend’s message lighting up the screen: “Which night are we having our date? I’m free all week, just say when.” I smiled, thinking about how we’d promised to spend more time together, to really be present. But as the clock ticked closer to closing, my manager reminded me that tonight I’d be handling the end-of-shift high-value transactions. The numbers had to be perfect—one slip, and the whole drawer would be off, and I’d be responsible. My boyfriend’s texts kept coming, sweet and expectant, while my mind raced with totals and receipts. I wanted to say yes, to pick a night and make him happy, but I couldn’t focus on anything except the pressure of balancing the register. My heart tugged in two directions: the warmth of his anticipation, the weight of my responsibility. I stared at my phone, torn, knowing I couldn’t give both roles what they deserved at the same time.
